citations.narrative:
On February 15, 2023 a visit to the facility found 6 breeding age female dogs, 4 St. Bernards and 2 Bernese Mountain
dogs, housed in the same sheltered building. There were also 3 non-neutered adult male dogs; a St. Bernard, a Poodle,
and a Bernese Mountain dog, in the same building. In addition, there were 8 St. Bernard/Poodle cross puppies and 4 St.
Bernard puppies. Following the owner’s request, the facility’s USDA Class A breeders license was canceled September
2, 2021. The owner said they were not breeding the Bernese Mountain dogs, but a posting on Puppies.com shows they
put up 2 Bernese Mountain Dog puppies for sale in December 2022. Puppies from at least 3 St. Bernard litters have also
been posted in the last year. A search of Certificates of Veterinary Inspection (CVI) by the Iowa Department of Agriculture
and Land Stewardship (IDALS) found that the owners of the facility have sold and shipped by air to other states at least 5
dogs since their license was canceled. This type of interstate commerce, when the owner is in possession of more than 4
female breeding age dogs, is regulated by the Animal Welfare Act and requires a license issued by the USDA. Continuing
to conduct USDA regulated activities without a license is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
